METHOD: Beat together 400ml of water, 45ml oil, 20ml honey, 40ml apple cider vinegar and one to two eggs (depending on size). Briefly mix into the dry ingredients with a hand whisk. Leave to stand and whisk again after 2 minutes to smooth out any remaining lumps. The consistency should be smooth, thick and creamy. Pour into a greased dumpy bread pan. Cover with an upside down bread pan. Bake at 180ºC for 60 minutes or until light brown and firm when tapped. Cool on a cooling rack under a cloth. After cooled to body temperature, cover with plastic to sweat the crust. When completely cooled down, slice thinly and freeze. (Can also be frozen on the second or third day) When frozen this bread keeps fresh for months as if baked minutes ago. To defrost, pop straight into the toaster (toast twice) for a delicious crispy toast. For a soft bread, wrap in a cloth and warm in the oven or microwave or until steaming. Founded in 1890 in Amsterdam by Gerrit van Voornveld the factory soon captured a central position in the market. During the 1890s an influenza epidemic caused a tremendous increase of the demand for cough suppressing liquorice. Van Voornveld's liquorice recipe proved to be the perfect remedy against an aching throat and lyrax. At the beginning of the new century, the liquorice factory was taken over and the new owners renamed it in Venco (Voornveld and Companions). The new name was a tribute to the founder of the company. After 1945 in the wake of the fusion between Venco and Red Band the factory moved to Roosendaal. Today Venco is a leading liquorice brand in the Netherlands which becomes increasingly popular abroad.

FARM TO BOTLE TO TABLE – The Olives are grown in granite soils aided by biodynamic cultivation, cold-extracted within 24 hours of being handpicked; and bottled on the estate. This signature Olive Oil is a careful blend of selected olive cultivars, resulting in a beautiful balance in taste and aroma.

Extra virgin olive oil isn't just for cooking; it's a luxurious condiment that elevates everyday meals into culinary experiences. Here's why you should make it a staple in your kitchen:

  • Purest Essence of the Olive: Extra virgin olive oil is the unrefined first press of olives, capturing their essence in its most natural and flavourful form.
  • Health Benefits Galore: Rich in antioxidants and monounsaturated fats, extra virgin olive oil can contribute to a heart-healthy diet.
  • Unleash the Flavour: Drizzle it over salads, pastas, vegetables, or even popcorn to experience a burst of rich, fruity, and peppery notes that enhance any dish.
  • Cooking Versatility: From searing meats to creating flavourful vinaigrettes, extra virgin olive oil's high smoke point makes it perfect for various cooking methods.
  • Invest in Quality: A bottle of extra virgin olive oil is an investment in your health and culinary enjoyment. Look for bottles labelled "extra virgin" and store them in a cool, dark place.

Bring the taste of the Mediterranean to your table with extra virgin olive oil! It's a healthy and delicious way to add a touch of luxury to your everyday meals.

Christmas Fruit Cake: A Festive Tradition

Christmas fruit cake, a beloved holiday tradition, is a rich, dense cake packed with dried fruits, nuts, and spices. Traditionally, it's soaked in brandy or rum for months, giving it a deep, boozy flavour. This festive treat is often enjoyed during the holiday season, either sliced and served with custard or cream, or as a small bite with a cup of tea or coffee.

One of the unique features of Christmas fruit cake is its ability to keep for long periods of time. The high sugar content and alcohol content act as natural preservatives, allowing the cake to be stored for months or even years. This makes it a convenient and festive treat to enjoy throughout the holiday season.

While Christmas fruit cake is often associated with the holiday season, it can also be enjoyed year-round. Some people prefer to serve it as a dessert after a meal, while others enjoy it as a snack or a light breakfast. No matter how you choose to enjoy it, Christmas fruit cake is sure to add a touch of festive cheer to any occasion.

Whole meal spelt flour is a type of flour made from the entire spelt grain, including the bran, germ, and endosperm. Spelt is an ancient grain that is related to wheat, but it is more easily digestible and has a higher nutrient content.

Whole meal spelt flour can be used in place of all-purpose flour in most recipes. However, it is important to note that spelt flour absorbs more liquid than all-purpose flour, so you may need to add a little more liquid to your recipes when using spelt flour.

Founded in 1890 in Amsterdam by Gerrit van Voornveld the factory soon captured a central position in the market. Instructions

Here's a step-by-step guide on how to make your own sushi at home:

Ingredients:

  • Sushi Rice: Short-grain Japanese rice
  • Rice Wine Vinegar: For seasoning the rice
  • Nori: Dried seaweed sheets
  • Fillings: Your choice of raw fish (sashimi-grade), cooked seafood, vegetables (cucumber, avocado, etc.), cream cheese, etc.
  • Soy Sauce: For dipping
  • Wasabi: A spicy green paste
  • Pickled Ginger: For cleansing the palate between bites

Equipment:

  • Sushi Rolling Mat: A bamboo mat for rolling the sushi
  • Sharp Knife: For cutting the sushi rolls
  • Rice Paddle: For spreading the rice evenly
  • Bowl: For mixing the rice and vinegar

Instructions:

  • Prepare the Rice:
    • Rinse the rice thoroughly under cold water until the water runs clear.
    • Cook the rice according to package instructions, but with slightly less water than usual.
    • Once cooked, transfer the rice to a large bowl.
    • Mix in the rice vinegar, sugar, and salt (seasoning mixture) while the rice is still warm.
    • Let the rice cool completely before using.
  • Assemble the Sushi Rolls:
    • Place a sheet of nori on the sushi mat, shiny side down.
    • Wet your hands slightly to prevent the rice from sticking.
    • Spread a thin layer of rice over the nori, leaving a small strip uncovered at the top edge.
    • Place your desired fillings in a line down the center of the rice.
    • Lift the edge of the mat closest to you and roll the sushi tightly, pressing firmly.
    • Continue rolling until you reach the end of the mat.
    • Moisten the top edge of the nori with a little water to seal the roll.
    • Use a sharp knife to cut the roll into bite-sized pieces.
  • Serve:
    • Place the sushi rolls on a plate and serve with soy sauce, wasabi, and pickled ginger.
  • Tips:
    • Practice makes perfect: Don't worry if your first rolls aren't perfect. The more you practice, the better you'll get.
    • Use high-quality ingredients: Fresh, high-quality ingredients will make a big difference in the flavour of your sushi.
    • Don't overfill the rolls: Too much filling will make the rolls difficult to roll and cut.
    • Keep your hands wet: Wet hands will prevent the rice from sticking to your fingers.
    • Experiment with different fillings: There are endless possibilities for sushi fillings. Get creative and try new things!

Additional Notes:

If you're using raw fish, make sure it's sashimi-grade and has been properly frozen to kill any parasites.

If you're new to sushi, start with simple rolls like cucumber rolls or California rolls.

Have fun and enjoy your homemade sushi!

Make a ball of dough with an electric mixer and kneading hook by mixing all the ingredients all at once. (If mixing by hand mix all ingredient with a wooden spoon and continue kneading on the table when all water is absorbed.) Transfer the pasta into a large pot of rapidly boiling water and boil until al dente. (+- 5 minutes) Strain off the water. Add 30 ml of oil and toss to prevent the pasta from sticking together.

Sushi-meshi (also known as Su-meshi , shari or gohan ) is a preparation of white, short-grained, Japanese rice mixed with a dressing consisting of rice vinegar, sugar, salt, and occasionally kombu and sake. It has to be cooled to room temperature before being used for a filling in a sushi or else it will get too sticky while being seasoned. Traditionally, it is mixed with a hangiri (a round, flat-bottom wooden tub or barrel) and a shamoji (a wooden paddle).

Sushi rice is prepared with short-grain Japanese rice, which has a consistency that differs from long-grain strains such as those from India, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Thailand, and Vietnam. The essential quality is its stickiness or glutinousness, although the type of rice used for sushi is different from glutinous rice. Freshly harvested rice (shinmai) typically contains too much water, and requires extra time to drain the rice cooker after washing. In some fusion cuisine restaurants, short-grain brown rice and wild rice are also used.

Sushi Rice need to be cooked in a rice cooker or steamed. Do Not boil with excessive water.

Our Psyllium Husk is graded for human and animal consumption.

Psyllium husk is sometimes included in horses' diets for specific health-related reasons.

Digestive health: Psyllium husk is rich in soluble fiber, which can help promote healthy digestion in horses. It forms a gel-like substance when mixed with water, which can help soften the stool and ease the passage of faeces through the digestive tract. This can be particularly beneficial in preventing or managing conditions such as colic or impaction.

Sand clearance: Horses grazing on sandy pastures or those fed on a substrate that contains sand may inadvertently ingest small amounts of sand over time. This sand can accumulate in the digestive tract and lead to complications. Psyllium husk has been used as a laxative in horses to help facilitate the removal of sand from the intestines. It works by binding to the sand particles and increasing the bulk of the faeces, aiding in their elimination.

Weight management: Psyllium husk can contribute to weight management in horses. As a source of fiber, it can provide a feeling of fullness, potentially reducing overeating and aiding in weight control.

When considering the use of psyllium husk for a horse, it is essential to consult with a veterinarian or equine nutritionist. They can provide guidance on the appropriate dosage, administration methods, and whether it is suitable for the specific needs of the horse. Additionally, psyllium husk should not be used as a substitute for proper management practices, such as providing clean water, feeding a balanced diet, and minimizing exposure to sandy environments.

Body_Html:
This spice mix is coarsely ground and mixed with whole spices to give your biryani the most aromatic and wholesome flavour. The recipe calls for cooking in "dum," a traditional method that helps retain all of the flavours within the layers of rice and meat.

Nimkish Mutton Dum Biryani Spice Mix is an all-in-one cooking solution that eliminates the need for onion, ginger, garlic, salt, or any other spice blend. No more worry about getting the spices ratio right, as we've already done that for you.

  • Nimkish Ready to Cook Spices are authentic, easy to use and super-delicious.

  • No added MSG, no artificial flavours, no added colours & preservatives.
  • Restaurant style flavours | Premium spices | 100% Natural Ingredients

Cooking Instructions

  1. To 500g mutton pieces, rub 2 tbsp ginger garlic paste (optional), 200g yogurt, 1 lemon juice, 6 tbsp oil and 1 pack of Nimkish Mutton Dum Biryani Masala. Mix well and keep aside for 30 minutes.
  2. Wash and soak 250g Basmati rice in 450 ml water for 30 minutes. Put the contents in a pan with 4 tbsp oil and boil until 70% cooked and water is absorbed.
  3. Put the mutton in a pressure cooker and keep on high heat until first whistle. Turn the heat to low and cook for 10 minutes. Open the lid once the steam has released.

  5. Add few strands of saffron to 200ml hot milk and steep for 30 minutes till colour draws out. Pour this saffron milk on the top evenly. Add 2 tbsp desi ghee on top of the rice (optional).
  6. Place the heavy bottom pan over tawa (flat pan), cover with lid and seal it with dough / aluminum foil wrapped all around the lid. Let it simmer for 30 minutes in dum (pressure). Turn off the heat and let it sit for 10 minutes.
Serve with mint raita.

Rolled oats are a staple whole grain, prized for their versatility and health benefits. They are made by steaming and flattening oat groats with large rollers, creating thin flakes that cook relatively quickly while retaining their hearty texture.

Linseed, also known as flaxseed, is a small, nutrient-dense seed that has gained popularity for its numerous health benefits. Rich in omega-3 fatty acids, dietary fibre, and lignans, linseed is often praised for its ability to support heart health, improve digestion, and promote hormonal balance.

These seeds can be consumed whole, ground into meal, or pressed into oil, making them a versatile addition to a variety of dishes. Ground linseed is commonly used in smoothies, oatmeal, or baking, while whole seeds can add a pleasant crunch to salads and yoghurt.

Linseed is also a popular ingredient in vegan and gluten-free recipes, often used as an egg substitute when mixed with water. Its nutty flavour enhances both sweet and savoury dishes, making it a pantry staple for those seeking a nutritious boost.

Incorporating linseed into your diet is an easy way to harness its health benefits, contributing to overall well-being with every bite.

Side-note: Linseed is a shorter plant, with lots of branches and lots of seeds. Flaxseed is taller (3 foot) with fewer branches. Therefore, linseed is good for creating oil and flax has longed been used to make linen, rope, and nets. The seeds are however seen as the same product.

Our Psyllium Husk is graded for human and animal consumption.

Psyllium husk is sometimes included in horses' diets for specific health-related reasons.

Digestive health: Psyllium husk is rich in soluble fiber, which can help promote healthy digestion in horses. It forms a gel-like substance when mixed with water, which can help soften the stool and ease the passage of faeces through the digestive tract. This can be particularly beneficial in preventing or managing conditions such as colic or impaction.

Sand clearance: Horses grazing on sandy pastures or those fed on a substrate that contains sand may inadvertently ingest small amounts of sand over time. This sand can accumulate in the digestive tract and lead to complications. Psyllium husk has been used as a laxative in horses to help facilitate the removal of sand from the intestines. It works by binding to the sand particles and increasing the bulk of the faeces, aiding in their elimination.

Weight management: Psyllium husk can contribute to weight management in horses. As a source of fiber, it can provide a feeling of fullness, potentially reducing overeating and aiding in weight control.

When considering the use of psyllium husk for a horse, it is essential to consult with a veterinarian or equine nutritionist. They can provide guidance on the appropriate dosage, administration methods, and whether it is suitable for the specific needs of the horse. Additionally, psyllium husk should not be used as a substitute for proper management practices, such as providing clean water, feeding a balanced diet, and minimizing exposure to sandy environments.

Red espresso is a unique and innovative beverage that offers a caffeine-free alternative to traditional coffee and tea. It originated in South Africa and gained popularity for its vibrant red colour and health benefits. Unlike regular espresso, red espresso is made from Rooibos tea.

To create red espresso, finely ground Rooibos tea is used in espresso machines, resulting in a rich, full-bodied drink with a distinct red colour and a slightly sweet and nutty flavour profile.

One of the key features of red espresso is its versatility. It can be enjoyed on its own, similar to a regular espresso, or used as a base for various coffee and tea-based beverages. Red cappuccinos, lattes, and iced drinks are just a few examples of the creative ways red espresso can be incorporated into different recipes.

Overall, red espresso offers a unique and flavourful alternative to traditional coffee and tea. Whether enjoyed on its own or used as a base for creative beverages, it provides a caffeine-free option with potential health benefits and a vibrant red color that is sure to captivate coffee and tea enthusiasts alike.

Dried apple rings are a snack made by slicing fresh apples into thin rings and dehydrating them until all the moisture is removed. The resulting apple rings are chewy and have a concentrated, sweeter, and more intense flavour than fresh apples.

Dried apple rings can be made at home using a dehydrator or oven set to a low temperature or purchased pre-packaged at most grocery stores. They are a popular snack choice for people who want something sweet and healthy, as they contain no added sugar or preservatives and are rich in fibre, vitamins, and antioxidants.

In addition to being a tasty snack, dried apple rings can be added to trail mixes, granola, and baked goods like muffins and bread. They can also be rehydrated and used in recipes for fresh apples, such as pies and crumbles.

Gluten-free baking powder is a type of baking powder that does not contain any gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. On the other hand, aluminium-free baking powder is a type of baking powder that does not contain aluminium, a common ingredient in many baking powders.

While there are no direct health benefits of using gluten-free or aluminium-free baking powder, they may be beneficial for people who have specific dietary requirements or sensitivities. For example, people with celiac disease or gluten sensitivity must avoid gluten in their diets to prevent negative health effects. Using gluten-free baking powder can help them avoid consuming gluten.

Similarly, some people may be concerned about the potential health effects of consuming aluminium. Although the evidence linking aluminium intake to negative health effects is limited, some people may choose to avoid aluminium in their diets as a precautionary measure. Using aluminium-free baking powder can help them achieve this.

It's important to note that baking powder is typically used in small quantities in recipes, so the potential health benefits of using gluten-free or aluminium-free baking powder may be minimal. However, for those who need to avoid gluten or aluminium for dietary reasons, these baking powder types can be a helpful option.

Psyllium husk - or psyllium fiber - is the outer layer of the psyllium seeds from the psyllium plant, Plantago ovata, and is considered a valuable source of fiber. It is made by milling or grinding to remove the seed’s outer layer, where the fiber is highly concentrated. This psyllium fiber is a non-digestible carbohydrate that can provide several health-related benefits.

Digestive Health:
It regulates digestion and forms a gel that moves through the digestive tract, helping trap and remove waste. (One of our biggest clients for Psyllium husk is a Veterinary Hospital who uses it to treat horses with sand colic!)

Putting the “glue” back in gluten-free baking:
Another “why” you would use Psyllium husks is to add it to gluten-free recipes which need a form of bonding to keep gluten-free flours from tasting like sand! You will thus likely find the ingredient psyllium husk in gluten-free baking recipes.

Help maintain healthy blood sugar levels:
When taken with meals, psyllium husk has been shown to help maintain healthy glucose or blood sugar levels.

Psyllium husk can be incorporated into your diet by adding it to smoothies, muffins, muesli or if you are not faint-hearted by mixing a tablespoon to a glass of water and quickly down it (it becomes a gooey gel within seconds!)

Note: you get two different Psyllium Husk products, the Psyllium Husk, and the Psyllium Husk Powder. Should you require large quantities, please indicate whether you prefer the powder. We stock the Psyllium Husk.

Coconut sugar, sometimes called coconut palm sugar, comes from the sap of the coconut palm tree - not the coconuts.

Harvesters tap coconut palm sap by cutting into the tree’s flower-bud stem to access its nectar. Producers mix the sap with water, boil it into a syrup, and allow it to dry and crystallize. Afterward, they break the dried sap apart to create sugar granules that resemble regular table or cane sugar.

Psyllium husk - or psyllium fiber - is the outer layer of the psyllium seeds from the psyllium plant, Plantago ovata, and is considered a valuable source of fiber. It is made by milling or grinding to remove the seed’s outer layer, where the fiber is highly concentrated. This psyllium fiber is a non-digestible carbohydrate that can provide several health-related benefits.

Digestive Health:
It regulates digestion and forms a gel that moves through the digestive tract, helping trap and remove waste. (One of our biggest clients for Psyllium husk is a Veterinary Hospital that uses it to treat horses with sand colic!)

Putting the “glue” back in gluten-free baking:
Another “why” you would use Psyllium husks is to add it to gluten-free recipes which need a form of bonding to keep gluten-free flours from tasting like sand! You will thus likely find the ingredient psyllium husk in gluten-free baking recipes.

Help maintain healthy blood sugar levels:
When taken with meals, psyllium husk has been shown to help maintain healthy glucose or blood sugar levels.

Psyllium husk can be incorporated into your diet by adding it to smoothies, muffins, muesli or if you are not faint-hearted by mixing a tablespoon into a glass of water and quickly down it (it becomes a gooey gel within seconds!)

Note: you get two different Psyllium Husk products, the Psyllium Husk, and the Psyllium Husk Powder. Should you require large quantities, please indicate whether you prefer the powder. We stock the Psyllium Husk.
